copulaStan: Fitting Bivariate Copula Models

copulaStan-intro.Rmd

Introduction

This vignette demonstrates how to fit bivariate copula models using the copulaStan package. The package supports Gaussian, Clayton, and Joe copulas with normal, lognormal, exponential, and beta marginal distributions.

library(copulaStan)
library(copula)

Example: Gaussian Copula

Normal + Lognormal Marginals 

seed <- 2024
set.seed(seed)
true_rho <- 0.5
n <- 2000

margins <- c("norm", "lnorm")
params <- list(list(mean = 0.8, sd = 2), list(meanlog = 0, sdlog = 0.8))
cop <- normalCopula(param = true_rho, dim = 2)
mvdc_copula <- mvdc(cop, margins = margins, paramMargins = params)
data <- rMvdc(n, mvdc_copula)

fit <- fit_bivariate_copula(data,
  copula = "gaussian", marginals = c("normal", "lognormal"),
  seed = seed
)
fit
summary(fit)
coef(fit)

Normal + Exponential Marginals 

seed <- 2024
set.seed(seed)
true_rho <- 0.5
n <- 2000

margins <- c("norm", "exp")
params <- list(list(mean = 0.8, sd = 2), list(rate = 1))
cop <- normalCopula(param = true_rho, dim = 2)
mvdc_copula <- mvdc(cop, margins = margins, paramMargins = params)
data <- rMvdc(n, mvdc_copula)

fit <- fit_bivariate_copula(data,
  copula = "gaussian", marginals = c("normal", "exponential"),
  seed = seed
)
fit

Beta + Beta Marginals 

seed <- 2024
set.seed(seed)
true_rho <- 0.5
n <- 2000

margins <- c("beta", "beta")
params <- list(list(shape1 = 2, shape2 = 5), list(shape1 = 3, shape2 = 4))
cop <- normalCopula(param = true_rho, dim = 2)
mvdc_copula <- mvdc(cop, margins = margins, paramMargins = params)
data <- rMvdc(n, mvdc_copula)

fit <- fit_bivariate_copula(data,
  copula = "gaussian", marginals = c("beta", "beta"),
  seed = seed
)
fit

Example: Clayton Copula

Normal + Lognormal Marginals 

seed <- 2024
set.seed(seed)
true_theta <- 2.0
n <- 2000

margins <- c("norm", "lnorm")
params <- list(list(mean = 0.8, sd = 2), list(meanlog = 0, sdlog = 0.8))
cop <- claytonCopula(param = true_theta, dim = 2)
mvdc_copula <- mvdc(cop, margins = margins, paramMargins = params)
data <- rMvdc(n, mvdc_copula)

fit <- fit_bivariate_copula(data,
  copula = "clayton", marginals = c("normal", "lognormal"),
  seed = seed
)
fit

Example: Joe Copula

Normal + Lognormal Marginals 

seed <- 2024
set.seed(seed)
true_theta <- 2.0
n <- 2000

margins <- c("norm", "lnorm")
params <- list(list(mean = 0.8, sd = 2), list(meanlog = 0, sdlog = 0.8))
cop <- joeCopula(param = true_theta, dim = 2)
mvdc_copula <- mvdc(cop, margins = margins, paramMargins = params)
data <- rMvdc(n, mvdc_copula)

fit <- fit_bivariate_copula(data,
  copula = "joe", marginals = c("normal", "lognormal"),
  seed = seed
)
fit

Mathematical Derivations

Gaussian Copula Log-Likelihood

Transformation to Uniform Marginals: U1=F1(X1),U2=F2(X2) U_1 = F_1(X_1), \quad U_2 = F_2(X_2) where F1F_1 and F2F_2 are the CDFs of the marginals.

Transformation to Standard Normal: Z1=Φ−1(U1),Z2=Φ−1(U2) Z_1 = \Phi^{-1}(U_1), \quad Z_2 = \Phi^{-1}(U_2)

Copula Density (ratio of bivariate to product of univariate normals): c(u1,u2;ρ)=11−ρ2exp(−12(1−ρ2)(z12+z22−2ρz1z2)+z122+z222) c(u_1, u_2; \rho) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\rho^2}} \exp\left( -\frac{1}{2(1-\rho^2)}(z_1^2 + z_2^2 - 2\rho z_1 z_2) + \frac{z_1^2}{2} + \frac{z_2^2}{2} \right)

Log-Likelihood: logc(u1,u2;ρ)=−12log(1−ρ2)+ρz1z2−12ρ2(z12+z22)1−ρ2 \log c(u_1, u_2; \rho) = -\frac{1}{2} \log(1-\rho^2) + \frac{\rho z_1 z_2 - \frac{1}{2}\rho^2 (z_1^2 + z_2^2)}{1-\rho^2}

Clayton Copula Log-Likelihood

The Clayton copula CDF: C(u,v;θ)=(u−θ+v−θ−1)−1/θ,θ>0 C(u, v; \theta) = \left(u^{-\theta} + v^{-\theta} - 1\right)^{-1/\theta}, \quad \theta > 0

The density (second mixed partial derivative): c(u,v;θ)=(θ+1)u−θ−1v−θ−1(u−θ+v−θ−1)−1/θ−2 c(u, v; \theta) = (\theta + 1) \, u^{-\theta - 1} \, v^{-\theta - 1} \left( u^{-\theta} + v^{-\theta} - 1 \right)^{-1/\theta - 2}

Log-likelihood: logc(u,v;θ)=log(1+θ)+(−θ−1)(logu+logv)−2θ+1θlog(u−θ+v−θ−1) \log c(u, v; \theta) = \log(1 + \theta) + (-\theta - 1)(\log u + \log v) - \frac{2\theta + 1}{\theta} \log(u^{-\theta} + v^{-\theta} - 1)

Joe Copula Log-Likelihood

The Joe copula CDF: C(u,v;θ)=1−[u‾θ+v‾θ−u‾θv‾θ]1/θ,θ≥1 C(u, v; \theta) = 1 - \left[\bar{u}^\theta + \bar{v}^\theta - \bar{u}^\theta \bar{v}^\theta\right]^{1/\theta}, \quad \theta \geq 1 where u‾=1−u\bar{u} = 1-u, v‾=1−v\bar{v} = 1-v.

Let a=u‾θa = \bar{u}^\theta, b=v‾θb = \bar{v}^\theta, S=a+b−abS = a + b - ab. The density: c(u,v;θ)=θu‾θ−1v‾θ−1S1/θ−2[S+θ−1θ(1−a)(1−b)] c(u, v; \theta) = \theta \, \bar{u}^{\theta-1} \, \bar{v}^{\theta-1} \, S^{1/\theta - 2} \left[ S + \frac{\theta - 1}{\theta}(1 - a)(1 - b) \right]

Log-likelihood: logc(u,v;θ)=logθ+(θ−1)[logu‾+logv‾]+(1θ−2)logS+log[S+θ−1θ(1−a)(1−b)] \log c(u, v; \theta) = \log\theta + (\theta-1)[\log\bar{u} + \log\bar{v}] + \left(\frac{1}{\theta} - 2\right)\log S + \log\left[S + \frac{\theta-1}{\theta}(1-a)(1-b)\right]
